results.title: Robert Browning: his life and poetry
results.brief_description: Surveys the biography and works of the Victorian poet Robert Browning, focussing on the revelation of dramatic monologue. The film shows the things from which Browning drew his inspiration and uses paintings, early photographs and scenes of unchanged parts of London and Italy to illustrate the events of his life. Selections of his poetry are read by constumed actors, emphasising the drama and psychological insight of his work. Narrated by Andrew Faulds.

results.title: Robbie the reindeer in hooves of fire
results.brief_description: Robbie the Reindeer has a big set of hoofprints to follow in - his father is Santa’s beloved Rudolph (he of red-nosed fame). Robbie has come to the North Pole to take his place on Santa’s team but he is a young reindeer who lacks direction and soon realises that he is not fit or disciplined enough to keep up with the others. He must firstly prove himself in the annual Reindeer races to win the respect of his teammates and the love of a girl. In the spirit of animator Nick Park’s ‘Wallace and Gromit’ series and written by some of Britain’s top comics, this is an animated adventure the whole family will enjoy. Voices include those of Robbie Williams, Jane Horrocks, Rhys Ifans, Ricky Tomlinson, Harry Enfield and Ardal O’Hanlon. Music by Mark Knopfler.

results.title: Robbery under arms [DVD]
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, ITC Entertainment, Jock Blair, Donald Crombie and Ken Hannam
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Rolf Boldrewood, “Robbery Under Arms” tells the story of the legendary and daring bushranger - Captain Starlight. Starlight (Sam Neill) is the renegade of a noble English family with a taste for fine wine, romance and other men’s cattle. Starlight also has a talent for robbery under arms and with his team, they set out on a trail of adventure and action that takes them through many parts of Australia; mostly in defiance of the law. Cast also includes Ed Devereaux.

results.title: Robbery under arms
results.creator_credit: Pacific Photo Plays and Kenneth Brampton
results.brief_description: Based on the Rolf Boldrewood novel, this film follows the two Marsden brothers and their adventures with the gentlemanly bushranger, Captain Starlight; their romance with local girls, their life on the goldfields and their eventual capture by the police after Starlight is shot. The brothers serve a long prison term, and emerge to start a new life with their patiently waiting sweethearts. Cast includes Kenneth Brampton, Roy Redgrave, S.A. Fitzgerald, William Pearson, Stuart McCrae, Witton Power, Jackie Anderson, H.D. Wise, Tian Hogue, Nan Taylor, Phyllis Ruthcen, Hilda Dorrington, Vera Archer, Austral Nichol, Betty Crock. Reconstructed version by the National Film Archive (ScreenSound).

results.title: Roar: Melbourne expressionism in the 1980s
results.creator_credit: Video Education Australasia, Traudi Allen and Peter Wiseman
results.brief_description: Formed in 1982, Roar Studios and the Roar group became synonymous with expressionism, abstract art and the emergence of a new group of talented young Australian artists that helped alter the future course of the teaching and exhibition of art in Australia. This was achieved through the breakdown of the stifling mores of the Australian art world of the time. Through interviews with artists from the original Roar group at a reunion exhibition at Roar 2 in the 1990s, critical discussion of the social circumstances and firm philosophies of the group as well as their key works, this program is an insightful study of one of the first artist run galleries and studios in Melbourne. It explores the experiences, international and local interests, and the diversity of artistic styles but shared influences of the artists who made it happen. It also discusses the significant impact of Roar on the facilitation of exhibitions for women and ethnic artists and on the emergence of an independent Australian art. The Roar artists profiled and interviewed include David Larwill, Pasquale Giardino, Stephen McCarthy, Jill Noble, Tony Mighell, Sarah Faulkner, Mark Howson, Peter Ferguson and Trevor Hoppen. The 26 minute documentary is followed by 20 minutes of extended viewing of stills of key artworks.

results.title: Roadworks
results.brief_description: Works on roads and bridges as carried out by the Country Roads Board in all parts of Victoria. Among these shown are the widening of old roads and bridges; testing local materials in field laboratories; experimental lengths of road surfaces; erecting an emergency Bailey bridge after the collapse of an old bridge; eliminating road/rail intersections (the Clifton Hill overpass); and redesigning major intersections for safe traffic flow.

results.title: Roads to Xanadu. Part 2: Episodes 3 & 4
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, John Merson and David Roberts
results.brief_description: Roads to Xanadu is an intriguing investigation of the dynamic interchange between East and West in the making of the modern world. Episode 3: “Dreams of Wealth and Power” investigates the different responses of China and Japan to the threat posed by Europe. Both countries recognised the need to modernise in some form, but it was the Japanese who forged ahead at such a speed that within forty years of opening their doors to the West, they were able to challenge the might of Imperial China, and even that of European colonial powers within Asia. Episode 4: “The Colour of the Cat” is the last episode of the series and it explores China’s most recent past and speculates about it’s future. Rated: G
